Taking care of yourself helps you be there for your children during tough times.

SourceText: Find someone you can talk to about how you are feeling.
Take a moment each day to listen to your breath as it rises and falls.
Are you losing your temper? Breathe in and out slowly five times.
Make sure to take care of yourself so you can feel better and be there for your family.
Remember to praise yourself each time you take steps to cope.
Thank you for joining us. Remember, you're doing the best you can. Be proud.
This tip is about making a routine for your children.
When we are in crisis, things can feel unfamiliar. Having routines helps your children feel safe and stable.
When you do the same things every day, it makes life more familiar for your children. It also makes them feel less worried and more secure.
โถ๏ธPress play to learn 3๏ธโฃ tips on making routines to spend time together with your children:
1๏ธโฃ **DO IT DAILY**
2๏ธโฃ **PLAY EVERY DAY**
3๏ธโฃ **PRACTISE BEING CALM**
Here are 3๏ธโฃ tips on making routines to spend time together with your children:
Even when it feels hard, try to have some activities that you and your children do every day for yourself and your children.
If you can, help children with daily routines like eating together and praying.
Try to set aside time to play or spend quality time with your children every day.
Playing with and talking to children for a few minutes every day helps them feel secure.
Ask children what they would like to do.
Listen to them, look at them, and give them your full attention.
Our children learn calmness and kindness from us.
Every day, try telling yourself a calming message.
Try โI can do this, I am trying my best.โ
Small amounts of time can help children feel safe and loved.
After this lesson, you can type {PLAY} to get some activity ideas to do with children.
Here are some regular activities you might want to try to do with your children:
Eat one meal together
Getting ready to sleep
Exercise daily
Daily play activities
Thank you for joining us. Parenting is not always easy. Well done for doing your best.
This tip is about helping your children cope with a crisis.
It is normal to be worried about your children, especially during tough times.
Children might face emotions and challenges they donโt know how to handle.
There are things you can do to help them feel better now and make them stronger for the future.
โถ๏ธ Press play to learn 3๏ธโฃ tips on how you can support your children during tough times:
1๏ธโฃ **LISTEN**
2๏ธโฃ **PRAISE YOUR CHILDREN**
3๏ธโฃ **PRAISE YOURSELF**
Here are 3๏ธโฃ tips on how you can support your children during tough times:
Children may be scared, confused and angry. They need your support.
Listen to your children when they share how they are feeling.
You can also encourage them to show their feelings by drawing pictures or writing poems.
Tell them whatever they are feeling is okay and give them comfort.
Ask children to help with day-to-day tasks, such as making food or cleaning.
Praise them for trying or doing well. This encourages helpful behaviour.
Praising children shows them that you notice and care.
Every day before you sleep, take a moment to praise yourself for trying to help your children cope.
Thinking of even one thing you are proud of can make a difference!
Thank you for joining us. Remember to also praise yourself for doing the best you can do.
This tip is about helping your children when someone dies.
Losing a loved one is painful for everyone, including children.
Children may feel overwhelmed and upset when someone dies.
Talking to your children about death can be hard, but it will help them make sense of what is happening.
โถ๏ธPress play 3๏ธโฃ tips on how to help your children when someone dies:
1๏ธโฃ **BE CLEAR**
2๏ธโฃ**ACCEPT FEELINGS**

SourceText: 3๏ธโฃ **SAY GOODBYE**
Here are 3๏ธโฃ tips on how to help your children when someone dies:
In simple terms, tell them the person has passed away and will not return.
You can add โTo Allah we belong and to Him we return. The person who has died is now in Paradiseโ.
If one of their caregivers has died, tell children who they will live with and who will look after them โ they often worry about this.
There is no right way for a child to react to loss. Children may act happy but still feel sad.
Listen to your child and tell them that whatever you are feeling is okay.
Do something together to say goodbye to the person โ a song, a letter or  reading Al Fatiha from the Holy Quran together.
Let us understand how children of different ages react to death.
Small children under the age of 5 years may ask if the person who has died is coming back.
They might hold onto you or other caregivers more, or start doing things they used to do when they were younger, such as wetting the bed.
Older children between 6 and 11 years old may ask more questions and want to understand what happened.
They may show their grief through anger and experience physical aches or pains.
Adolescents and young teenagers from around the age of 12 years will wonder about why things happen.
Their reactions will vary and can include lack of interest, anger, extreme sadness and poor concentration.
Thank you for joining us. Parenting is full of difficult conversations. Take a moment to care for yourself.
This tip is about protecting our children from sexual violence and responding to it.
During difficult times, children are more likely to face dangers like sexual violence.
Sexual violence means doing or trying to do something sexual to someone that they donโt want to happen.
This can include things like threatening, pressuring or forcing someone to have sex, or touching them in a sexual way,
Sexual violence can be committed by a stranger, a friend, or even a family member
โถ๏ธPress play to learn 6๏ธโฃ tips for protecting your child from sexual violence:
1๏ธโฃ **NO IS OK!**
2๏ธโฃ **TELL A PERSON OF TRUST**
3๏ธโฃ **RECOGNIZE**
4๏ธโฃ **LISTEN**
5๏ธโฃ **RESPOND
6๏ธโฃ **COMFORT YOUR CHILD**
Here are 6๏ธโฃ tips for protecting your child from sexual violence:
Teach your child that no one has the right to touch them or make them uncomfortable.
Remind them that their body belongs to them and if anyone touches their body, it is haram
Practice saying "no" loudly and strongly together.
Remember, you can do this with words and with body.
Talking about this with your child helps protect them.
Tell your children that abusers often trick by giving gifts, pretending to be kind and supportive. Once violence happens, the abuser asks them to keep sexual violence a โsecretโ.
Remind them that they donโt have to keep secrets from their parents or a person they trust.
Tell your children they donโt need to feel ashamed about the violence they survived.
Let them know itโs always okay to talk to a trusted adult, like a parent or a teacher, if someone makes them feel uncomfortable.
3๏ธโฃ**RECOGNIZE**
Itโs not always easy to see, but some signs may show a child has been hurt:
๐ตStart doing things they used to do when they were younger, such as wetting the bed
๐ต Unexplained physical complaints
๐ต Sudden changes in mood or behaviour
๐ต Holding onto you or other caregivers more
๐ต Struggling with peers or school โ such as having fewer friends, doing worse in class, or skipping school
๐ต Risky or self-harming behaviours, like cutting, stealing, or using substances
4๏ธโฃ**LISTEN**
Take a deep breath so you can respond calmly.
Ask yourself, โWhat does my child need right now?โ
Let your child share with you what they need. Avoid criticism.
Notice what they are feeling and tell them what you notice so they feel heard.
Tell your child that you believe them and are there for them.
5๏ธโฃ**RESPOND**: What might help what is going on?**
You might need to help your child talk about their feelings or redirect their focus.
You might need to talk about the actions that you or your child could take to help with what has happened. In case of sexual violence, you and Your child need to go to the clinic.
Right now, your child needs you to be there for them with love.
Remind them that it is not their fault what other people did to them.
Remember, you can always type {HELP}  and get information about resources in your community where you may receive help.
6๏ธโฃ **COMFORT YOUR CHILD**
It can be hard to see your child feeling upset or confused, but there is a lot you can do to support them.
๐ Reassure them itโs not their fault and they are safe and loved.
๐ Remind your child again that you love them and that together, you two will find solutions. Thank them for sharing with you.
Thank you for joining us. Talking about sexual violence with your children will go a long way to protect them. It is not easy but necessary. They are lucky to have you. Be proud of yourself.
Keeping children safe can feel overwhelming, especially when dealing with unexpected challenges.
In such moments, having a clear plan will help you and your children know what to do to be safe.
Press Play โถ๏ธ to learn 3๏ธโฃ tips on how to keep your children safe in an unsafe situation:
1๏ธโฃ **TALK**
2๏ธโฃ **PLAN**
3๏ธโฃ **ASSURE**
Here are 3๏ธโฃ tips on how to keep your children safe in an unsafe situation:
Talk to children about what is happening in a way that they can understand.
Talk to them about things that are not safe.
Identify a meeting point and make a plan in case you get separated.
Keep children with you or with someone you trust all the time.
Planning with children helps them feel safer too.
Assure your children that you will do everything to keep them safe.
Encourage them to share anything that worries them with you.
Be proud of your efforts and try to take care of yourself too.
Thank you for joining us. Remember that you are not alone and that there are things you can do to keep your children safe.
Human trafficking is when someone is tricked, forced, or pressured into doing something they donโt want to do for someone elseโs benefit.
This can include being forced to work, commit crimes or perform sexual acts so the human trafficker can gain money or favours.
It can happen to anyone, anywhere, including your own home.
This lesson will help you protect your child by teaching them how to stay safe and what to watch out for.

Here are๏ธ 5๏ธโฃ things for you to do to help protect your children from traffickers:
1๏ธโฃ **TEACH YOUR CHILD** what human trafficking is and who traffickers can be.
Traffickers are people who lie or pretend to be friendly to trick children into going with them or doing things they donโt want to do.
Traffickers can be anyone - men, women, couples, or even someone your child knows and trusts.
They might offer gifts, make big promises, give lots of compliments or ask them to keep a secret to gain trust.
Teach your child to listen to their feelings. If something feels weird or scary, trust your gut โ your feelings are probably right.
3๏ธโฃ **GET AWAY SAFELY**
Before leaving with anyone, even someone your child knows, tell your child to make sure they feel safe.
Tell your child to make sure someone else knows where they are.
Teach them to not go anywhere with strangers even if they are nice to them.

If they feel unsafe, teach them to stay calm. Walk away if they can, go to a safe place with people around, and ask a trusted adult or authority (like a teacher, police officer, or security guard) for help.
4๏ธโฃ **TALK TO TRUSTED ADULT**
Tell children to talk to a trusted adult if they feel confused or worried.
Let your child know they should tell you or another trusted adult if anyone, even someone they know:
๐ด gives them gifts
๐ด makes big promises, or
๐ด asks them to keep secrets that make them feel uneasy.
Remind them they can always talk to you, no matter what.
5๏ธโฃ **TEACH YOURSELF**
Learn how to spot signs that something might be wrong.
Watch for changes in your childโs behaviour or mood.
Also look out for if your child is:
๐ต Going to places that are unusual for them
๐ต Getting gifts or money they canโt explain
๐ต Hiding who they talk to or where they go
๐ต Getting nervous, upset, or secretive when using a phone or going online
These signs donโt always mean something is wrong but they are good reasons to check in with your children and show them you care
Thank you for joining us. Talking to children about human trafficking can be hard for both you and your children. Remember to be kind and patient with yourself and your children.
Being in a shelter can be lonely and stressful for children.
There are things you already know how to do, like doing daily activities and practising self-care. These can help you and your children feel safe and secure in a new place.
Press Play โถ๏ธ to learn 3๏ธโฃ new tips that will help you to support your children in a shelter:

3๏ธโฃ **REASSURE**
Here are 3๏ธโฃ new tips that will help you to support your children in a shelter:
If possible,take a comfort item from home with them to a shelter
Decorate the shelter together, with notes or pictures for the walls if you can.
Find something to smile about together.
Share one good thing that happened at the end of each day with your child - no matter how small.
Try to reassure your children as often as you can.
For younger children, you may want to give them a hug or hold them when they are feeling scared.
For older children, let them know that you are here for them and give them the space to talk to you.
Thank you for joining us.  Remember that your children learn from you, so taking good care of yourself every day will help them take care of themselves too. You can do it!
